title: What Rafa Benitez said about Sunderland's infamous beach ball goal vs Liverpool
text:

It is a clip that has now been seen thousands of times, and repeated on football comedy compilations over and over again.

But one thing that often isn't said about Darren Bent's infamous beach ball goal for Sunderland against Liverpool 10 years ago today is just how calmly Rafael Benitez took it.

At a time when Liverpool's Spanish manager had been railing against ownership chaos and "facts" about Sir Alex Ferguson's Manchester United , he was strangely calm about what he described as "a special situation".

"We had bad luck with the goal, but the team were not doing well so that is something we have to fix," he said after the game at the Stadium of Light, where 'Bent's' goal was the winner.

(Image: Getty Images)

"The other things you cannot control. I couldn't see what had happened. We were asking and they told us but you cannot change things."

Others of a Liverpool persuasion didn't take things as lightly though.

"I've seen the goal played back I don't know how many times now and you look at the reactions on different peoples' faces," Bent told Sky Sports recently.

(Image: Getty Images)

"Pepe Reina's face, Glen Johnson's face, Jamie Carragher's face… everyone is like 'what's happened here?!'"

Reds goalkeeper Reina still remembers the goal as his tweet last year showed , while Callum Campbell, the 16-year-old Liverpool supporter who threw the ball, received threats from fellow supporters went it happened.

While if Steve Bruce, the Sunderland boss at the time, was trying to sound magnanimous about a goal that really shouldn't have stood then he certainly failed.

(Image: Getty Images)

"I thought it was a deflection off a player," he said after the game.

"I have to say when I have just seen it there, if anybody knew that rule - that it is supposed to be a dropped ball - then you are a saddo.

"They have got it on telly with the guy who threw it on and it's got Liverpool crests all over it. What a shame."

(Image: Getty Images)

We'll leave the last word to Bent, who is well aware that he'll always be associated with the beach ball - which is now in National Football Museum in Manchester.

"It was a freak accident but it was a nice goal to score," he said..

"I finished with 106 Premier League goals - although some people say 105! But it's a weird bit of history that I'm proud to be a part of."
description: Darren Bent famously found the net - with a bit of help - on this day back in 2009
